reviewText: ... that this movie haven't got a official, restored/ remastered DVD Release and I have never seen it before?Well sure is, in the german speaking parts of the world, classic movie are be showed really rare on the TV. And when they do always the same.To this movie: a really interesting movie, made in the first year of the WW2 with great actors Norma Shearer ("The Women", "Romeo and Juliet", "Marie Antoinette") in her 3rd last movie, Robert  Taylor, Philip Dorn, Conrad Veidt (in his US Debut), Mr. + Mrs. Alfred Bassermann and the GREAT former silent movie star "Alla" Nazimova.Philip Dorn is playing a "good" Nazi Doctor who's helping a Escape.THE DVD:Attention: the picture is not restored and not remastered so the picture quality is not good: has some damages but its still watchable!!!Has no subtitlesTrivia: Norma Shearer's Brother Douglas Shearer was "recording director", worked also on this movie and on "The Wizard of Oz", "The Women", "San Francisco", "The great Waltz" and won in his career incredible 12 academy awards. His first one was for "The big house" (1930). Norma and Douglas were the first oscar-winning brother and sister.He also co-developed MGM's Camera 65.

reviewText: This beautiful rendering of Ethel Vance's runaway bestseller has sensitive performances from Robert Taylor and Norma Shearer and restrained direction from Mervyn LeRoy. Radio fans will be surprised to see Arch Oboler's name among the writing credits, as the writer who took over Lights Out and thrilled audiences for years helped Marguerite Roberts retool Vance's tense and exciting melodrama in to Norma Shearer's last great film. The role of Countess Ruby von Trek was beefed up by MGM and while it remains overall Taylor's film, who is outstanding, it is Shearer's final sacrifice to get he and his mother out of Germany the viewer will always remember. Having seen this many times over the years, it remains my favorite of the lovely Shearer's films sans her husband, Irving Thalberg. Legend has it she went around incoherently asking people if they were Irving when she was relegated to being cared for in her old age.Robert Taylor is excellent as the American traveling to Germany to discover what has become of his mother, who had gone back to sell the family home. Silent film star Alla Nazimova hams it up a bit at times but is effective nonetheless as his mother, Emily Ritter. Mark's mother had helped refugees escape the Nazis and would have been wiser to stay in America. Mark isn't sure what has happened to his mother, and has only a letter and postmark to go by. Shearer is regal and luminous in fur from the first frame, a glorious flower fronting the beautiful alps in the background. Ruby is an American by birth, a widow who remained in her adopted country when her German husband of title passed on. More worldly than the innocent Mark, she at first refuses to help, urging him to return to the United States where it is safe.It becomes even more dangerous for the American as his questions have reached the ears of the Gestapo. But not all in Germany are of the same mind about their country's direction, and when he discovers his mother has been interned in a concentration camp, a desperate and exciting plan to get her out is hatched and aided by them. Philip Dorn as the doctor who helps fake her death so that Mark can claim the body, and Felix Bressart as the old family friend sent to pick up the coffin are excellent. In a kind gesture to her silent screen past, Shearer afforded Nazimova a meaty role here, and she makes the most of her screen time after a long absence. Shearer is marvelous as a woman with conflicting loyalties. The mistress of General Kolb (Conrad Veidt) who has protected her from harm thus far, her true feelings are for Mark. A daring plan to escape with them so she and Mark can have their happiness plays out with tension and excitement in this glossy melodrama. The ending will come as a surprise.Tense and exciting at times, with restrained performances and a fine adaptation of Vance's novel, this glossy production is MGM at their best, and gorgeous Norma Shearer just the way we'd like to remember her. Bonita Granville gives a noteworthy performance as the nosy and misguided Ursula. Released in 1940, this film makes little bones about the climate in Germany while offering classic film fans some glossy A+ entertainment. A real winner.

reviewText: "Escape" is an incredible film when you consider it came out in 1940. The plot concerns a German citizen (Alla Nazimova) imprisoned in a concentration camp and sentenced to death for "treason", and the attempt of her American son (Robert Taylor) to free her. This is one of the very first films to cover this topic. In "Night Train to Muncih" (1940) Margaret Lockwood is arrested, imprisoned, and eventually escapes from a concentration camp with the help of a German undercover agent (Paul Henreid), and while conditions are sparse they are hardly bleak nor is there any mention of deadly consequences.In "All Through the Night" (1941) from Warner Bros. a girl's mother is in a concentration camp called Dachau, but there is no hint about conditions therein. In "Once Upon a Honeymoon" (1942), Cary Grant and Ginger Rogers are in Poland and barely escape from being sent to a concentration camp as well as being sterilized. We get the sense that it's not a good place to be, but no real insight into what goes on."Seventh Cross" (1944) actually deals with the conditions of imprisonment. The film takes place in1936 and involves the escape from a concentration camp by seven German citizens (writer, farmer, circus performer, school master, clerk, mechanic and a political activist). This is the first real portrayal of "work" camp, showing the harsh conditions.But here in 1940 we have one of the very first portrayals of actual conditions as well as the fact that concentration camps were places where people went to be executed.FWIW - while there were very few films about concentration camps, there were several anti-Nazi films in the pre WW 2 period, the best of which are "Confessions of a Nazi Spy" (1939), "Clouds Over Europe" (1939), "The Mortal Storm" (1940), and "The Great Dictator" (1940).Handsome and energetic Robert Taylor (1911-69) plays an American trying to find out what happened to his mother, but everywhere he goes and everyone he speaks to will reveal nothing and only advise him to leave the country. Taylor achieved success in more than 70 films like "Magnificent Obsession" (1935), "Camille" (1936), "A Yank at Oxford" (1938), "Ivanhoe" (1952), and "Knights of the Round Table" (1953). He was so enamored with flying after he made "Flight Command" (1940) that he became a private pilot and once the war broke out, joined the Navy Air Corps as a flying instructor.MGM boy genius Irving Thalberg never tired of seeing his beloved wife Norman Shearer (1902-83) in films, especially period pieces. Thalberg rescued her from a reasonably undistinguished though profitable career in silent films when they married in 1927 and he put her in "The Divorcee" (1930) for which she won the Oscar. She went on to achieve 6 Oscar nominations for her work on films like "Marie Antoinette" (1938) and "Romeo and Juliette" (1936). Once Thalberg died, Shearer lost interest in making films, but served out her contract. Despite her lack of interest, I think this is her best film performance as American born Countess (by marriage) who is torn between her desire to help Taylor and her romantic ties to a German General played by Conrad Veigt.Conrad Veidt Veidt was one of the best known German silent screen stars, appearing in "The Cabinet of Dr Caligari" (1920) among other classics. An anti-Nazi married to a Jew, Veidt fled Germany in 1933 when Hitler took power. He moved to England and then the US in 1940 where, ironically, he played the Nazi in several films such as "Nazi Agent" (1942), "Above Suspicion" (1943), and most memorably "Casablanca" (1942). Veidt died of a heart attack in 1943.Handsomely chiseled Helmut Dantine (1918-82) makes his film debut as a porter. Dantine was an Austrian who spent time in a concentration camp and a fervent anti-Nazi in real life, but he often played a Nazi on screen, most memorably in "Mrs. Minerva" (1942) and co-starred with Flynn in "Edge of Darkness". In later life he hooked up with Sam Peckinpah and produced and appeared in several of his films including "Bring me the Head of Alfredo Garcia" (1974) and "Killer Elite" (1975).Mervyn LeRoy (1900-87) directs. He started out directing with "Little Caesar" (1931) and went on to achieve an Oscar nomination for "Random Harvest" (1942) and DGA nominations for "Quo Vadis" (1951), "Mister Roberts" (1955) and "A Majority of One" (1961) and a Golden Globe nomination for "Gypsy" (1962). Among the nearly 80 films he directed were "I am a Fugitive from a Chain Gang" (1932), "The Wizard of Oz" (1939), and "Thirty Seconds Over Tokyo" (1944).Critics raved about the film. The NY Times' Bosley Crowther called it "the most dramatic and hair-raising picture yet made on the sinister subject of persecution in a totalitarian land." Modern Screen called it a "gripping and spine-tingling melodrama" and said that "both Norma Shearer and Robert Taylor are excellent."The film does have a few problems. By chance Taylor meets the doctor who has the responsibility of executing Taylor's mother, and by chance the doctor has on him a letter intended for Traylor after his mother is dead. In addition, the production values are minimal.BTW - the book makes it clear that Taylor's mother was guilty of helping Jews, but in the film this is never mentioned, although there are hints.The top grossing films in 1940 were "Fantasia", "Pinocchio", "Rebecca", "Boom Town", and "Santa Fe Trail". "Rebecca" won for best picture, James Stewart ("Philadelphia Story" was best actor, and Ginger Rogers ("Kitty Foyle") was best actress. Other notable films that year were westerns like Spencer Tracy in "Northwest Passage", Gary Cooper and Walter Brennan in "The Westerner", and Errol Flynn in "Virginia City", comedies like Irene Dunne and Cary Grant in "My Favorite Wife", Cary Grant and Roz Russell in "His Girl Friday", and W.C. Fields as "The Bank Dick" and with Mae West in "My Little Chickadee".Interestingly enough war films were not so popular in 1940 - Joel McCrea in "Foreign Correspondent", Charlie Chaplin in "The Great Dictator", and James Stewart and Margaret Sullivan in "The Mortal Storm" were among the only war films released that year.Bottom line - a good suspense drama that is one of the very first actively anti-Nazi films to highlight the problems in concentration camps.
summary: One of the first glimpses of life in Nazi Germany

reviewText: Make no mistake, during the Golden Age of Hollywood, the studios were factories that mass produced their product, releasing hundreds of formulaic films each year. That does not, however, mean the product is any less pleasing than something hand made; after all a luxury Cadillac is also mass produced. Escape is fine entertainment, despite the fact that it is little known today. American Mark Preysing arrives in Germany, desperately trying to saving his famous actress mother from execution in a Nazis concentration camp. He attempts to enlist the aid of another American, Countess Ruby von Treck, who is the mistress of a high-ranking Nazis official. Initially she refuses, partly out of fear, but also out of loyalty to her ailing lover, General Kurt von Kolb. The screenplay, written by Arch Oboler and Marguerite Roberts, based on the novel by Grace Zaring Stone, is a taut, tense thriller that is both exciting and horrifying, moving along at a quick clip. It is also exceedingly well acted by all involved, down to the most minor of characters. Norma Shearer, although she receives top billing, is superb in a supporting role, beautifully portraying that delicate dance of choosing between conflicting desires. One choice is dangerous yet feels right, but involves a personal betrayal, while the other option, although easier, violates her deeply held convictions. Robert Taylor, often dismissed as a pretty boy, gives a dynamic performance of a genial, loving son who soon finds himself mired in terror and deceit. Alla Nazimova, a famous silent screen star, is marvelous as the mother, and she downplays her sometimes overblown style. But in some ways, it is Conrad Veidt's film. He plays General Kurt von Kolb as charming, gentle, and so considerate of Ruby that it is easy to understand her affection for the man, and her unwillingness to betray him. Yet there is also his brutal, steel core, his complete commitment to the Nazis policies and politics, and that dichotomy both fascinates and repels. Felix Bressart, who usually plays the comic relief, gives a heartfelt performance as the frightened family friend who proves to be among the bravest Preysing encounters. A surprise to me was Bonita Granville, who plays one of the students of the Countess, Ursula. Usually Granville irritates with her fast paced, frantic delivery, but this time, she is surprisingly evil as the traitorous student. The cinematography by Robert Plank, who also did Three Musketeers and Royal Wedding, is sumptuous, beautiful, and very atmospheric. The only criticism I might offer is that the sets are obviously studio backstage creations, but I do realize that location sets were virtually impossible at the time. But I nitpick! This is a wonderful film, highly entertaining, and very thought-provoking.

reviewText: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer (MGM) presents "ESCAPE" (1940  - (104 min/B&W;) Starring: Robert Taylor, Norma Shearer, Conrad Veidt, Ala Nazimova & Felix BressartDirected by Mervyn LeRoyBased on a novel by Ethel Vance, Robert Taylor plays a young American who is the son of a widowed European woman (Alla Nazimova). The mother has been imprisoned in a German concentration camp, compelling her son to ignore America's neutrality and attempt a rescue. Sneaking into German-occupied Europe, Taylor is befriended by a countess (Norma Shearer) who is the mistress of a Nazi general (Conrad Veidt).This is an underrated film, MGM doesn't pull any punches on their feelings about Hitler, and his concentration camps of Nazi Germany. Not the run of the mill you are use to from MGM during that time in Hollywood.Shearer gives one of her best performances, also Veldt's character as the charming but ruthless Nazi General, still gives us chills.This was a gutsy move on MGM's part, as we were not at war with Germany for over a year.BIOS:1. reviewText: Out of seemingly nowhere, Warners have released about four hundred of theirs and MGM's B grade back catalogue. Many of these films have never been released on DVD or video, so this is reason to celebrate and some of these films (such as "Escape") were great movies of their day, some (like this one) a little dated, but still worth having, others were flops of the time (like "made in Paris", "One on One","The Eddie Cantor Story") that are still worthy of inclusion in any collector's library.There are also some obscure musicals such as "I Love melvin" and "Give a Girl a Break".  Yet the big warning is that the films haven't been restored, so we get scratches, bumps, end of reel circles in the corner,some scenes more faded than others. I imagine these have been taken from archival videos of the film, yet there is no attempt to go back to the masters to restore the film as we are so used to having with most DVDs today."Escape" is a fine juicy nostalgic melodrama of the day, that sits perfectly as a companion piece to "The Mortal Storm" well justified anti nazi propaganda films of the early 40s, that now look quite historic in their somewhat accurate depiction of this time in Germany. If you can get past Robert Taylor's hammy acting, it's quite a little gem, but, again, be aware, these are not prints that have been restored. Worth having regardless, though I do wonder why AMAZON HAVE JACKED UP THE PRICES BY SEVEN DOLLARS from what is on offer on the Warner Archive website??????

reviewText: "Escape" (1940) is based on Grace Zaring Stone's (writing as Ethel Vance to protect her daughter who was essentially living the life of Norma Shearer's countess in Europe) rather pedestrian 1939 novel of the same name. In the novel, Emmy Ritter, an actress who had fled to America, foolishly returns to Nazi Germany to sell her house. She is arrested and condemned to death. Somewhat illogically (insert "literary device" here) she receives a stay of execution for an emergency appendectomy. Her son Mark comes to find her and spirits her away from the concentration camp infirmary.The book and the film suffer from the contrived logic of too many literary devices. On one hand a totalitarian state wants its citizens discussing any Draconian efforts to suppress dissent, as the whole idea is to make an example of a specific dissenter. On the other hand there is nothing to be gained from persecuting a public figure who has already left the country, particularly when the state wants to encourage the emigration of dissenters. In the service of its contrived plot, the movie reverses the logic of both these strategies.The saddest part of the film is that it was just an attempt by MGM to commercially exploit the world's fascination with all things National Socialist. Hollywood aggressively catered to the prevailing isolationist sentiment in the country. Incredibly the first courageous releases did not come until just a few months before this film, Warner Brothers "Confessions of a Nazi Spy", MGM's "The Mortal Storm", and Jules White's Three Stooges short "You Nazty Spy!" With the prevailing anti-Semitism in the United States, there was little commercial appeal to disputing Nazi racial theories, and to protesting the segregation measures they began implementing as early as 1933. There was nothing in the Neutrality Acts (legislation beginning in 1935 that restricted commerce with belligerent nations) that prevented Hollywood from releasing films with elements that appealed to the United States government to permit additional immigration of European Jews. "Escape" could have been such a film but most likely the idea of going in that direction was never even entertained by those making the money decisions about this milk toast screenplay. Perhaps MGM felt burned at the box office from the confrontational tone of "The Mortal Storm" and decided to avoid anything controversial with this release."Escape" is an embarrassing film that fails on so many levels that it is scary to find that anyone today takes it seriously. Made in 1940 but set in 1936 Germany, it does a staggeringly poor job of capturing the conditions, spirit, and mindset of Germany in either year.In 1936 Hitler was the most popular leader in Europe, the vast majority of Germans were (with good reason at that point) euphorically celebrating the recent improvements in their lives. Bonita Granville's character is the film's is the only reasonably accurate characterization, although they have her embracing militarism rather than National Socialism. The only real dissenters were the groups that Hitler had disenfranchised. Far from wanting the expense of mass liquidations, Hitler wanted these groups to emigrate at their own expense. The main obstacles being that they leave their wealth and property behind and that they find countries willing to accept them. A woman selling her house to another German would not have been an issue, selling her house to a Jew might have been. Were she later deported as a political enemy she might have been restricted from taking the proceeds from the sale out of Germany.I suggest reading Judith Baumel's "Unfulfilled Promise" to understand the shocking unwillingness of our society to take meaningful action to save a generation of Jewish children (let alone adults).  "Escape" is testimony to Hollywood's complicity in this failure and would be more accurately titled "Escapism".Although not particularly popular today, "Escape" belongs on a short list of the most over-rated films. It is a modestly made studio film, technically representative of its era, and requiring considerable suspension of disbelief to experience any feeling of suspense. It's a good showcase for a young Robert Taylor with a nice supporting performance from Conrad Veidt, in his Hollywood debut and probably deeply troubled by the film's lack of substance.Today the value of "Escape" is not in how it treats the attitudes in Germany in 1936 but how it reflects the head-in-the-sand commercialism of the United States in 1940.

reviewText: Mark Preysing (Robert Taylor) is on a mission to save his mother from the Nazis in Europe. Although he is an American, his mother is not. She is the well-known actress Emmy Ritter (Alla Nazimova) whose heyday twenty years ago has made her a beloved household name, but the Nazis are keeping her in a concentration camp to be executed. It takes quite some time for Mark to discover where she is, and although it seems hopeless that she might make it out of the country alive, he must try. Enlisting the help of fellow American Countess Ruby von Treck (Norma Shearer) and his mother's friend Fritz Keller (Felix Bressart), he risks everything to save her life.This is an exciting movie with plenty of tense moments. The cast is wonderful; Shearer is brilliant in one of her last films, Taylor is an excellent and strong leading man, and it is wonderful to see Nazimova playing what she was in life, an older woman who was a very well known actress two decades before. It is remarkable how youthful her face was in spite of her age (61) and her difficult early life. Conrad Veidt is exceptionally menacing as the Nazi General who is suspicious of the American and protective of the Countess.Although the ending leaves us wanting more, it could hardly have been ended another way. This is a stylish and well-made example of what classic Hollywood was capable of.

reviewText: Anyone familiar with Norma Shearer and Robert Taylor know that these movie stars from the 30's and 40's are nothing short of terrific.  The story centers around Taylor whose mother is in a Nazi prison and he tries freeing her.  However, it is all but impossible,  and this is where Norma Shearer's character fits in.  Needless to say, a romance between the two ensues despite the fact that Shearer is in a close relationship with a bigwig Nazi officer.  Emotional scenes peppered with some tense moments and the interesting ending all make for another fine achievment in the annals of Hollywood's WWII film era.
